properties.description: The public plaza at S. Dixie and US 1 has an existing infrastructure that needs just a little help to make it an outstanding area for people to relax, gather, eat, rest and play.  Given the palm trees, however, architectural installments that provide shade, more comfortable seating areas and a flare of artistic style would dramatically change the atmosphere.  From temporarily painting trees to holding chalk festivals, this hardscaped plaza is of a large enough scale to offer the nearby residents a plethora of engaging opportunities.
properties.title: Southern Comfort
properties.details: This component, in a series of proposals, is one of the most vital.  The large area grants more potential for group activity than many other sites along the M-PATH.  Its Metro Rail location provides travelers with effective, efficient access and the surrounding community can use it as a versatile, mixed park.  People of all ages and backgrounds would benefit from the opportunity to utilize this public space.  Whether hosting a family picnic, meeting friends or wandering through by accident, the addition of minor amenities to this already existing plaza can effect the lives of everyone around it by providing the opportunity for community members to expand their list of fun places nearby and experience a shared, neighborhood environment.

properties.description: Coral Morphologic proposes to highlight what we think are the most overlooked aspects of Miami Beach’s finest public park: its tropical fish and coral limestone walkway. The defunct ferry slip at the easternmost end offers unprecedented opportunity for the public to enjoy schools of colorful tropical fish at South Pointe Park (without getting wet!).  This location is like Miami Beach’s very own (free) public aquarium... but sadly there are no comfortable seating areas to fully appreciate the Park’s abundant marinelife. Likewise, the South Point walking trail features a diverse trove of fossilized corals crystallized in its iconic Keystone pavers that frame its 2000’ length alongside Government Cut popular.
properties.title: South Pointe Park Tropical Fish Observation Benches and Fossilized Coral Walk
properties.details:
These subtle park additions will significantly improve the opportunities for the public to engage with the environmental beauty of Miami Beach. We have documented over 50 species of tropical fish living along South Pointe Park. The addition of benches along the defunct ferry slip will allow people to sit quietly and enjoy the serene beauty of the coral reef fish swimming in turquoise water. 

To showcase the coral fossils within the walkway itself, a digital map (accessible by smartphone) will be made such that anyone can locate and identify these natural artforms as they stroll through the Park. Signage at several locations in the park will inform the public how to access this digital map.

comments.comment: Easy to implement with broad educational appeal for everyone, this one is a no-brainer to implement.

properties.description: The goal of Shades of Miami is to combine art and urban place-making principles to creatively address one of Miami's biggest but basic needs: shade.  In doing so, we also help reach the broader goal of improving the pedestrian experience.  This will be done by taking selected areas in Downtown Miami and covering the crosswalks and adjacent publics spaces with a covered canopy composed of brightly colored umbrellas/parasols.
properties.name: Shades of Miami
properties.title: Shades of Miami
properties.details:
Two main issues we seek to address:
1) Improvement of pedestrian condition:  From an urban planning and place-making perspective, pedestrian activity represents an important aspect of the health and vitality of a city.  In Miami, some of the challenges faced in the urban core include intense heat and little overhead protection.  This project seeks to enhance the pedestrian experience and thereby create comfortable public space for people.  
2) Attention to the need for shade:  Part of the installation presents an opportunity to explore the need for shade in order to reduce the urban heat island affect.  By bringing attention to the need for shade, we seek to inspire further action, most specifically an increase in tree canopy in the urban areas.

comments.comment: I tremendously agree regarding the need for shade in Miami and your artful solution for it.  If given the opportunity to implement,   would like to partner with you for my project "Sound Garden at Bayfront Park." You can find the blue dot on the map, I make mention if the umbrellas in my project proposal.  Hope we can link-up.

properties.description:
By activating underutilized public spaces between many of the great attractions in downtown Miami, we can create small pocket parks that make it more inviting and enticing to walk this main corridor and explore its many offerings.

The Stephen P. Clark Government Center employs thousands of people and countless more walk through its doors every day. Yet the park space behind this center is severely neglected. With a water fountain, areas for sitting, shade trees, and a Metro station nearby, this pocket park has the potential to be a vibrant space for the community if only it had the right programming.

We will create a public space festival to showcase various ways in which a pocket park can be activiated with various installations and programs to inspire passersby to activate other spaces in the downtown corridor.

Our focus to program this pocket park is “Seeing the Future,” recognizing that Miami is still a very young city and to create a space where art and science collide, where design and the environment meet, where health and innovation intersect. This project aims to showcase to Miami residents the possibilities of what our city, of what our community can be in the near and distant future. We want to highlight Miami’s heritage, the various cultures, aspects of the environment, public health awareness, and education and innovation through art.
properties.name: Public Space 2014 (PS2014)
properties.title: Public Space 2014 (PS2014)
properties.details:
Active, successful, and iconic public spaces from around the world have many features in common – access to cultural events and galleries, breathtaking views, a variety of dining and shopping options, and access to public transportation hubs.

So why doesn’t Miami have an active and iconic downtown space like a Times Square or Millennium Park? Actually, we do! The Adrienne Arsht Center for Performing Arts, American Airlines Arena, Bayside Marketplace, Bayfront Park, and even new developments such as Museum Park and the Miami Visitors Center…they’re just not connected.

In between all these great attractions are typically vacant parking lots and unused pocket parks just waiting to be programmed and activated. They're waiting for residents, businesses, and organizations to take ownership and activate these pocket parks to give people a reason to walk along the downtown corridor and make it a more vibrant community.

properties.description: Residents, partners, and OLCDC are working to improve Opa-locka’s Magnolia North neighborhood (formerly “The Triangle”) by continuing development of the new Magnolia North Community Park to be more inclusive for teens, adults, veterans and the disabled population. Phase I, completed in early 2014 with the help of over 250 residents and volunteers, included the planning and construction of a playground for kids under 12, a walking path and domino tables. Phase 2 will address the community’s desire for physical and environmental education opportunities for adults. We will collaboratively transform two vacant lots adjacent to the park into outdoor fitness stations, an educational garden and picnic area.
properties.title: Installing Fitness Stations to Complete Phase 2 of the Magnolia North Community Park
properties.details: There is no gym or fitness center in the City of Opa-locka, and the closest ones are 1.5-2 miles away. They also require a membership fee unaffordable for many Opa-locka residents, 39% of whom live below the federal poverty line. The outdoor fitness stations in Phase 2 of the park’s development will allow Magnolia North residents and those from adjacent neighborhoods to become more physically active with free access to quality workout equipment.  Adults who bring their child to the playground can also exercise to improve their own physical well-being.  This helps promote an on-going culture of healthy lifestyles for families, outdoor activities and community interaction.

properties.submitter_name: Ross Torrence (Youth Advisory Board, Miami Children's Initiative)
properties.description: My idea is to put to good use an empty lot next to the Miami Children’s Initiative KaBOOM! Playground by creating a gym inside an open shipping container. The Liberty City Collaborative hosted by Miami Children’s Initiative would help me get second-hand gym equipment, and we could create an indoor gym by repurposing a large container.
properties.title: Indoor Gym for a Healthier Lifestyle
properties.details: This gym would benefit many people in the neighborhood since there are no free gyms available. Families can stay fit and active by exercising. It will also keep the kids safe since when they are out of school.

comments.comment: This is a wonderful youth in Liberty City who has a bright future!  I love this idea!
What an awesome idea. Love that there is  focus on fitness.
I totally support the idea of free gyms! What a great idea. I wonder if it could be multiple crates set up in a formation that allows people to have space and interact.

properties.description: This vacant lot sits among housing in an area where there are no parks nor green spaces. The idea is to provide some shade trees, benches and a track if possible. (Not sure who the lot belongs to but it has been vacant for years. Maybe at least something temporary may be done while owners decide what to do with it)
properties.title: Community park
properties.details: walk around, go jogging, walk their dogs etc.

properties.description:
1. Repurpose the existing, under-utilized bayfront parking lot (Parking lot #5) by creating green space for activities like yoga, pilates, stretching and relaxing while including benches for our community to congregate in front of the beautiful bay
2. Take down the fence running along the west side of the boathouse (which the city of Miami will do at no cost) and repurpose the area between pool, concession stand, and the boat launch/parking lot. 
3. Create waterfront walking/bike trail, including vita course equipment at proper locations, connecting the south side of the existing pedestrian trail, around the volleyball court and connecting again to the existing trail north of the pool.
properties.title: Morningside Park Common Spaces Project
properties.details:
-Project will greatly increase visibility of and community access to one of Miami’s most beautiful parks and its most valuable asset - the waterfront.
-Improve community awareness of the park’s active lifestyle amenities (kayaking, canoeing, sailing) while simultaneously enhancing and beautifying the facilities that serve one of Miami’s most diverse neighborhood/communities 
-Will help create community centered spaces that can simultaneously serve active/sporting uses as well as more gathering place type activities
-Trees, planters, and other enhancements (e.g., wifi access points) can be added throughout pathways and common areas so that park patrons can sit, relax, & enjoy the tranquility of the park & the harmony of Miami's grand bay.

comments.comment: Great proposal - lets get this done!
Love it! Can't wait.

Tom actually makes a great point - less than one person per day of the year is using that boat launch, and yet it takes up a huge amount of space on the waterfront with asphalt.  Convenience for a few shouldn't triumph over the greater good for the many.  I go to the park probably 300+ days out of the year with my dog and two year old daughter, and I think its a shame to have most of our waterfront land basically unusable between it being fenced off or rarely used tarmac.

And we're not even saying eliminate that launch or prevent all motorized watercraft use - just limit that to specific times and utilize the parking lot to the north for the trucks that haul in your boats.  Last - yoga is not the only suggested use of such converted greenspace; people can relax, stretch, or just gather in places along the water that will further beautify the neighborhood's greatest asset. 

It's hard to make everyone happy with a proposal, but that wasn't the aim here.  The aim is to improve the park and one of its most valuable public spaces.  The motives of a few privileged individuals who may have to take advantage of one of the city's slightly more inconvenient options if such an aim is achieved shouldn't be the prevailing logic to prevent it going forward, in my view.

Tom D. could not be more mistaken.  The boat ramp at Morningside does not get 500 boat uses a year.  What it does get, is more than 500 hookers, drug users and dealers that park in the area because nobody is around.  The volleyball court gets used all the time, especially by kids in the summer camp and on the weekends by picnickers. I would I agree that is very convenient for Morningside resident who have boats (all 5 of them) to have a private place to launch their boats but the needs of the entire community should come first and not just the ones with boats.

Please note that the parking lot in question is used about 300-500 times if not more per year by boaters, especially in summer, to launch their boats from the public ramp and park their vehicles and trailers. Obviously the person making this suggestion to repurpose the lot is sadly under informed and making assumptions as to its use. I am a boater and park user. I live in Morningside directly across from the park. I launch my boat in the park many times a year as do several other boaters both from in Morningside and around the Upper East Side. It would be unconscionable to remove this resource from these taxpayers who use it for boating, fishing, access to the picnic islands and Biscayne Bay and communing with nature in the bay. In the summer it is also a very desirable backup for boaters who know about it, because the ramp at 79th along with all of the other ramps in MDC are shut down on the weekends around 1 in the afternoon, during the months of May thru September, due to overcrowding and lack of parking.
Removing the fencing around the most pristine, secluded, and beautiful green space and picnic area of the park, along with the dock to view the bay is a great idea. This fence has denied access to the public for over 14 years and many many people, and MCA boards, have asked for its removal, and no one seems to know why it was put up. This would also allow the 1+ acre  green space for activities like yoga, Pilates, stretching and relaxing for our community to congregate in front of the beautiful bay. It should also be noted that for the use of these activities there is a 1/3  acre green which is open to the community directly, along with a large shade tree, which is never utilized though it has free access for any of these activities,  directly adjacent to the boat ramp on the north side.
So please, please, don’t address a space as be being underutilized which is so important to the community of boaters who in fact do use it. This is not a minority of park users as the yoga and Pilates group would be, who have got the whole park to use, along with many more pristine area’s to pick from.
If you want to target a truly underutilized area, target the beach volleyball court which I’ve never in 6 years since it was put in, seen used for that purpose, and it is directly on the bay also. Cover it with grass, put in shade tree’s, and utilize that space as a green space. It was a bad idea requested by a small minority at one time, so small in fact, we couldn’t locate them.
I love this proposal. This project would have such a positive impact on so many families and people living in and around the Morningside area. A park make-over is long overdue.

Paula T. could not have stated it better.  Here at the City's 2nd largest park, why are cars getting the best view(s) of Biscayne Bay?  This plan would do wonders towards solving this issue and benefit parkgoers from the numerous neighborhoods of the Upper Eastside and abutting communities who visit Morningside Park daily.
Perfect

Fantastic idea.  The parking lot has the best Realstate of the park, and should be devoted to people use and not parking cars.  Also connecting the trail makes so much sense.   Thank you for submitting this idea.

I think this would be a great project! Not only would it promote a healthier lifestyle for the community, but would also have a positive impact in our property values.  The community benefits and the City benefits (additional real estate tax revenue).  It’s win – win!!!

Fantastic idea.  Couldn't agree more with importance of increasing access to the waterfront -  one of Miami's most beautiful, but too often inaccessible assets.   Morningside Park is already a gem.   These suggestions would further maximize use and enjoyment of the Park.
Extending the bay walk along the bay behind the pool and trimming vegetation to enhance the view is a great idea and will increase the park usage.
Great park for the local community and all of Miami. Wonderful location and activities for everyone...part of what makes a city pleasant for all its people
Great idea, Morningside is beautiful park that needs a bit of a facelift.  Having a designated area in front of the Bay to stretch out before and after a run through the neighborhood would be great.

properties.description: The Miami Rugby Club (est.1969), presently fields a youth program of U-12, U-14, U-16, U-19 players, a men's side, a women's side and coaches both FIU & UM Rugby teams. The club has no home with permanent rugby goal posts and field in which to practice or play. This area is an empty lot in the back of Ruben Dario Park. Three lighted multipurpose fields side-by-side with a clubhouse/changing room & parking would greatly enhance this empty lot and help youths to indulge in worlds 2nd most popular sport(Olympic sport).
properties.title: Multipurpose Sports Fields (Rugby,Soccer,Lacrosse,Field Hockey)
properties.details: Visiting teams from Europe, British ships, play Miami Rugby  regularly as well as their regular match plays versus teams in S.Fla. If Miami Rugby had a permanent facility they would host an Annual International Rugby Tournament bringing in teams from Argentina, Uruguay and Europe. This would greatly help the local economy as well as rugby in Miami. (To maximize field usage Miami Rugby would sponsor welcome field hockey, soccer and lacrosse users as well.) Doral area is ideal with local hotels, eateries and ethnic demographics.

comments.comment: This would be a great step in the development of youth sport in Miami as well as grow an already successful Miami RFC.
Ideal location.  Easily accessible and not to distant from any Dade/Broward location.  Irrigation is always important.
Great idea for Ruben Dario park, would love to see a rugby venue in Miami to attract a growing sport.
Great idea     It would benice to have a field we can call home
It's a shame that a local club with roots going back to 1969 has no place to call home. This seems like a win-win for the community and Miami Rugby. Great idea!
I can help with my licenses if we need them, and connections to equipment and work
Great idea!  I work nearby and know that area is not used!
Definitely a plus for Doral and Miami Dade in general.

properties.description: Enhance the area under and around the FPL electrical lines to create a linear park between Kendall Drive and SW 100th Road /(Don Shula Expy).  Could be phased project, starting with a loop, paved pathway for walking, jogging and biking.  Loop can be designed to be a 1 mile loop.  Future phases could further enhance and engage the public by providing fitness stations at different intervals.  Other potential future phases could include a kids park, a dog park, sand volleyball court(s), etc.
properties.title: Kendall Linear Park, Fitness Loop
properties.details: Provides a safe path for residents to walk, jog or bike without the worries of "sharing" the road with Miami's overly aggressive drivers.  Once at the park, no need to cross any roads.  This would also create a more manicured and better kept landscape area than currently provided by FPL.  As a resident who lives in close proximity, I would be a frequent user of this unused land.  It would beautify the neighborhood, especially for those that back up to the property.

comments.comment:
Excellent ideas!  we need all the activity & exercise possible;
and this will help all of us!!

I would go one step further. There is a bike path in planning along the Snapper Creek Canal (north of Kendall Drive). I would extend this path north of Kendall drive until it meets the canal trail, the Snapper Creek Trail.

properties.submitter_name: Youth from the Liberty City Collaborative
properties.description: We the students at Miami Northwestern Sr. High idea is to create a bike sharing service for the Liberty City community. This idea will improve Liberty City by increasing the amount of exercise activity. It will help us make healthier choices as well as reducing children who are innocent bystanders by providing quicker and safer way home and reduce air pollution.
properties.title: Sharing on Wheels
properties.details: Our idea will make our Liberty City community better for many reasons. There is a lack of transportation in the area which we live. Our bike sharing program will offer awesome transportation to the kids and adults of Liberty City. The benefits of this program will result in transportation to various amount of places such as school work, important meetings etc. It will reduce a lot of health hazards for young people and adults. Lastly, it will be a form of entertainment. Allowing citizens to go out and enjoy themselves on nice day.

comments.comment: I agree with both comments above - what would be the plan for sustaining the program? What government or community agencies or community members would be involved?
I love, love, love this idea!  They worked so hard to bring this idea to life and it is possible to create a sharing experience in Liberty City, particular with proper community buy-in and ownership.
This idea would require security for the bikes and they can be costly to rent. It also requires annual budgets, it is not a one time investment

properties.description: The old Fountainebleau terrains have been sold and are being built with residential and commercial development. Some tracks have been open to the public but most is getting built over. There are only two really small parks in that whole area so the need for parks is extremely necessary. Since some of the trails, trees and lakes are already there, why not do sort of a linear park that connects all the lots that were sold. This is not only easy, since most of it is already there, but beneficial since it would be connecting commercial and residential areas. It would not only represent a place to run, walk or bike for exercise purposes but for transportation as well thus reducing traffic, a much needed help.
properties.title: Fountainebleau Linear park
properties.details: Would be able to bike or walk to commercial areas, exercise and thus reduce traffic and improve the residents' health and well being.

properties.description: The Leadership Learning Center is an After School Program in Little Havana for middle school students in the neighborhood.  Currently, the students don't have an area for recreation due to construction.  The program is in jeopardy of losing a Children's Trust grant if they are unable to provide a safe recreation space for the kids.  A vacant land  (90'x50') adjacent to the after school facility was donated for the students to have a mini-park.    Although the property has been donated, it is not in any condition for the program to operate as a recreation space.  The Marlins Foundation has prelimarily agreed to contribute by leveling the space and providing fill, sod and grass.
properties.title: Leadership Learning Outdoors
properties.details: This new space would provide children in the area a safe, clean and supervised place for recreation.  It can also open the door for additional partnerships to provide public access to a safe, clean place for the neighborhood.

properties.description: is to build a state-of-the-art health and wellness facility designed for disabled.  Physical fitness is a necessity for people who are healthy, but this is even truer for disabled people whose bodies deteriorate without exercise. There is no full service gym facility for them anywhere in the County.  This gym would include an accessible training center, indoor heated hydrotherapy pool, healing room, juice bar, and community lounge with resource library. The project organizer is the Sabrina Cohen Foundation, a non-profit dedicated to providing a better quality of life for people living with paralysis, which is currently in discussions with the City of Miami Beach regarding a proposed location on 76th Street and Collins Avenue.
properties.title: Fitness for ALL
properties.details: achieve physical fitness even if they are disabled, injured or in a wheelchair.  Clients at the fitness center would include disabled, senior citizens and wounded warriors.  They would engage in a full program of physical and aquatic therapy, adaptive yoga and meditation programs, nutritional counseling, massage therapy, art and music classes, peer counseling and life coaching. Such activities would strengthen their bodies, alleviate depression, and empower them to be active members of society.  This facility, located in a one-of-a-kind seaside destination, would attract both residents and visitors who have demonstrated that they are eager for this and would travel to such a facility.

comments.comment: vote everyday!

You are so right with this idea. Staying fit boosts morale as well as physical strength. As a fit senior, I know what it has done for me. For a person with challenges, being fit is critical to their wellbeing.

I workout regularly. If I suffered an injury, and was told to work out even more to reduce atrophy but was unable to find a gym that is capable of adapting to my limitations, so I declined in health and could not enjoy work outs, I would be so upset. This is something that is well overdue. Let's do this!

It is a great idea.. Since I become overweight (obese will be the right term), I cannot find any gym to acommodate my ever changing body...This is a great wonderful idea, for senior citizens too... Sabrina is a great thinker...
The proof is in the pudding my dear look how far you've come mentally and physically through your new found "workout" regime. I only hope they pick your idea so others can benefit
I can think of so many people who would benefit from this project.   Great idea!  Let's get this done.

http://ideas.ourmiami.org/place/169841
Sabrina, always inspired to do good in others.  I wish you all the success there is and that your inspire  ideas open a positive outcome in the community.

This is truly an innovative idea that makes sense in so many ways. Most importantly of course, it provides heretofore unavailable options to so many out there lacking finances, information, hope or a combination of all. As previously stated, economics are obvious, but also, here is a golden opportunity for MB to shine. Where MB has worked so diligently cultivating its rightful place internationally across all venues, this is an idea whose timing couldn't come better. Agreed that all eyes will be watching MB's fresh new inspiration. Brilliant.

Only recently did I become aware that "special" exercise equipment exists which can be used by those who are physically handicapped. properties.submitter_name: John Wesley Allen, Jr. (Global Green Ads)
properties.description: The area around 104th Ave in West Perrine has become an urban wasteland.  Global Green Ads proposes that the city of Miami outfit each bus stop and park in this area with solar powered advertising.  The idea is to provide a cost effective way to push positive messages and habits through digital advertising in maximum visibility areas within this urban community. The ads can include healthy eating and exercising tips,  while also promoting businesses in the area that support this initiative.  In addition, the advertising space made available could generate the money needed for the maintenance and upkeep.
properties.title: THE SEE HEALTHY, BE HEALTHY PROJECT.
properties.details: This idea could transform not only this community but other urban and unincorporated areas in Miami that are impoverished and often forgotten, through positive images in advertising that wont cost much to implement.  Scientifically, if you see an image a number of times, it registers in your subconscious.  The premise is to penetrate the minds of the people in this community with progressive images, thereby changing the landscape of the community itself.  The area around 104th Ave in West Perrine specifically, (named after Dr. Perrine, a founding father of Miami) is key in the history of the entire city of Miami, which many people don't know.

properties.description:
It would be great to have a boardwalk from the Deering Estate's canoe ramp thru the mangrove to the South End of Park at canal 173 St and Old Cutler connecting both parks  
Matching the boardwalk  that now exists in the Deering Estate (which charges admission to enter)
properties.title: Mangrove boadwalk
properties.details: This park welcomes families to see the bay and  the boardwalk  would provide an educational stroll thru the mangrove

properties.description: Move parking spots off the curb to use the lane / space between the curb and the new parking lanes as a dedicated and protected bike lane in certain areas.
properties.title: Bike Lane Redesign
properties.details: It would help protect bikers from traffic and would keep bikers from interfering with traffic.

properties.description: With three concurrent GREENMEANSGO events (10mi race; 5K family fun run/walk; 10mi bike) all Miamians will have the opportunity to experience first-hand the potential of the underutilized M-Path space. Local bands will be invited to set up & play at each of the 8 stations to cheer participants on.  The final stop, Dadeland South, will be transformed into a full park with sod for all participants to enjoy.  Tapping into a community of runners and cyclists who too frequently end up on the wrong side of a car, and into the burgeoning interest in and need for family fitness options, participants will literally feel the potential of transforming this underutilized urban space into a safe, appealing enduring community asset for fitness and fun.
properties.title: GREENMEANSGO Family Run/Fun Walk/Bike Event on M-Path
properties.details: The M-Path along US1, from Vizcaya to Dadeland South stations, is underutilized by & intimidating for pedestrians & cyclists.   The GREENMEANSGO multi-event family fun day will transform it into the multi-use urban park that it could be & can become.  Particpants would return to their starting points via MetroRail, thereby demonstrating how easy the rail is to use even with a bike!  By hosting the family Run/Fun Walk/Bike event, motorists, cyclists & pedestrians alike will see and experience for themselves the transformation that could occur with the future vision of the GreenLink, the grassroots initiative to transform the M-Path into a world-class mobility corridor (walking/biking/exercise path) & linear park (thegreenlink.org).

comments.comment: Count me in!  I would run this event with pleasure as I know it would bring an clear focus to what will eventually spring up along this underutilized path

I am delighted to see "green" in Miami!  As we grow and the limited land we have continues to be covered with concrete, creating vast areas of heat.  This space not only gives  Miami a wonderful extended park, it creates an area for  the natural breeze  to go through.  This gives back to the city what we have lost in certain areas.    This creates a lovely area for individuals to meet, walk, exercise and  understand how great the metro-rail  is.  
Congratulations on believing our beautiful city can grow and change, for the better!!!!
What a wonderful transformation.  I look forward  to seeing the completion of the project and attending the events.  Kudos to you
yes it needs to be used more....the less cars on US 1 the better

comments.comment: As a real estate agent I can see the value of adding such an interesting and beautiful green area to our city. Great selling point for all properties accesible by Metrorail!  I can't wait!!
Sounds like a ton of fun!

A community endeavor of this scale will do as much to bring people together in pride as it will in the creation of a functional linear park. Not to mention, it's span of 10 miles will make it accessible to so many communities along the way. 
Win-win!
Fantastic idea!!!
Great opportunity for a family outing.  Could enlist the Boy Scouts, Boys and Girls clubs and schools on the area to participate.
please note the correct link to the organization is www.thegreenlink.org - pardon my typo above!
This is the perfect way to get Miami excited about the Greenlink!!!
Brilliant idea !!!
This could be the best thing for Miami in a very long time.

What a wonderful idea! I would make an extra trip to Miami to participate in this event! I have ridden this path several times on my bike from Coral Gables to Vizcaya in order to avoid the dangerous roads without bike lanes and it was one of the more unpleasant experiences I have had biking. I live in Winter Park, but would contribute to a project that would make such a huge impact on the city.

properties.submitter_name: Miami Dade College School of Architecture + Broadway Avenue Development Group (BADG)
properties.description: Implement a children's playground in a contained neighborhood in Liberty City to serve kids who don’t have safe access to any community park. BBB is proposed to be located in an empty lot at the corner of NW18 Ave with NW69 Terr, across from Broadway Park which attracts only adults. BBB is designed to serve kids age 1-5, who live in a neighborhood confined between two major arterial roads, NW17 and NW22 Avenues. BBB, a kiddy play space that anchors a garden experience, is a design-build project to be developed by Professor Marcia Lopes de Mello's architecture students. This project receives support from MDC Earth Ethics Institute's Global Sustainability and Earth Literacy Studies program and Institute for Civic Engagement and Democracy.
properties.title: BUILDING BLOCKS ON BROADWAY
properties.details: Integrate children as contributing members of the broader community, so they can feel useful and valued. Have kids interacting and connecting with nature, safely and securely, in a welcoming and child-directed environment where young children initiate their own activities. Appreciate and value nature by playing with structures that are made from reclaimed trees and made of materials  upcycled from creatively repurposed waste or useless products. Engage young minds in a play area surrounded by organic forms and textures and excitement found in nature. Offer children a play area that favors unstructured play where they can have a great time coming into contact with new tactile surfaces and enjoy the great outdoors within their city.

comments.comment: What a wonderful idea with such a positive outcome. Bravo!

This is a very moving project that will empower the whole Liberty City community, and promote education through work and real-life experiences. Having met with the community members in the past, I am aware of the huge need for this, and confident they will take full advantage of this initiative, and apply learnings from it to future projects that also aid the city.
Taking a vacant lot and turning it into something that will bring young children a sense of achievement is truly admirable.

Involving the community, especially our young members, in physical activity while engaging with nature is certainly the way to towards a healthier and more enjoyable Miami. This project is mindful of both people and place. Great work!
Uma proposta universal que serve para muitos países pelo mundo, principalmente o Brasil. Um grande projeto social que pode ser realidade com a colaboração da arquitetura. Parabéns!!!!
This is awesome!
Creators of this movement, contact me via my personal email. I may have resources that can help your vision come true. ldfuentes@live.com
This is a great idea that will definitely have a positive outcome!

Its admirable to have faculty who give back to the community while building educational experiences that support sustainable practices among the youth. Great idea! I will share it among my social media followers!

comments.submitter_name: Gail Yale -Griffin, Professor of Architecture and Design
comments.comment: I agree that all the children of Miami deserve safe play and learning spaces. These become the foundation of individual and  neighborhood civic awareness, where each individual and group  become initiated as to the need care for our macro and micro communities - the land, its facilities, natural and creative amenities, potential for positive change and practices, opportunities for fair play and community involvement. Using sustainable and recycled materials as well, botanical and biological inventiveness  can provide a laboratory for further consideration of  best practices towards educating our greater public and our officials to the awareness  of  selecting and using our land for humans and nature in more forward thinking ways. And, yes  urban farming, plus trees ,can be considered part of this. Professor Lopes de Mello your thinking is right on!

This is a fabulous and very altruistic idea.  What a fantastic opportunity to have MDC students learn hands-on, while providing such a wonderful benefit to members of our south florida comminity. This project will lead to life altering gains for the children, the students and the community at large.  Congratulations and thanks to Professor Lopes de Mello

I am very impressed by this initiative to make our neighbourhood more lively and more human. It is very important that academic institutions become more active outside their own borders. This project is an excellent example of how universities should proceed. Congratulations, Prof. Lopes de Mello!
I would like to express my strongest support for  this BBB project as even small urban parks can make a world of difference for their users. Professor Lopes de Mello has proposed a brilliant idea.

Urban parks, gardens, and recreational open space promote inner-city revitalization. I think this is a great idea for low income families in the are, specially for the kids who can have a place to play and convey.

Several years ago I worked with Professor Mello and her Miami-Dade College students while serving as an AmeriCorps VISTA member. The children of Liberty City deserve a safe play space, and I believe this project is a much-needed addition to the area. Please consider BBB as a 2014 Public Space Challenge project!

properties.description: Close Flagler Street every Sunday from 8 am to 12 noon. Local residents may use the street to walk, ride their bikes, or enjoy breakfast or brunch from the local restaurants.
properties.title: Flagler Street Sunday Bike and Walk
properties.details: ... enjoy the outdoors, exercise, as well as  help energize downtown Miami on Sundays.

comments.comment: Great idea for those of us who live Downtown and visitors alike.

properties.description: In December, the short lifespan of Miami’s largest temporary park and only skatepark was served with an eviction notice. A place where more than 50 kids of all ages gathered at anytime.  My idea is to reinstall the Grand Central Skatepark, as a pop-up skatepark that would take place once a week for a month in the unused parking lot space of downtown Miami. Skateparks provide a safe social venue for the local youth who have been displaced, who otherwise may sneak into abandoned areas, unsafe lots, or take the risk of skating the streets with traffic. This park will raise awareness to provide a safe community space for Miami’s youth to stay active, healthy outdoors and empowerment through their sport.
properties.title: Pop-Up Skatepark in our Downtown!
properties.details: The Grand Central Skatepark was a ground breaking model for public space development here in Miami, recreating a blighted piece of downtown for minimal costs. After, less than 10 months on the three-year lease, the park space was sold to developers, they had to go. Since the eviction, they have been looking for another place to re-create a skate park.  The pop-up skatepark will give opportunity to do just that. It allows residents to see the creative potential and uses for the unused space. This will keep the youth involved until a more permanent place to skate is determined. The idea is not just about skateboarding; it’s about providing a low-cost approach to continue to improve our downtown area.

comments.comment: This is a perfect idea! The skate park will provide safety and is a great way to make use out of the space versus ideas like a farmers market, etc that are already widely available in miami.
I think it is great idea. Community should stick together and provide for the youth.
That could be a great idea for the winter! Makes some snow and have a few hours of fun :)
Now if only it were possible to have a snowboard park in Miami.

properties.description: BP 4 Life aims to place a public, outdoor exercise trail with targeted workout stations around lively Biscayne Park so the entire community can be as active as the kids dangling off the playground!  An outdoor, easily accessible, free fitness trail with workout stations that include simple, low cost installations and sign posts detailing helpful exercises would promote fitness for all ages in the heart of Biscayne Park, an urban community with an open park that serves residents and members of surrounding communities. Biscayne Park already boasts an activities field, basketball court, playground and tot lot.  It is also home to a recreation center with indoor activities. This fitness trail is the perfect complement to what the park offers.
properties.title: BP 4 Life
properties.details: Why should the kids have all the fun? The BP 4 Life Fitness Trail and workout stations will get parents on their feet and off the picnic tables. It is an ideal way to get and stay active; parents can workout during the day while keeping an eye on the kids having fun on the playground equipment. A gym membership can be extremely costly, and not all have daycare facilities for parents. But everyone using the BP 4 Life Fitness Trail will gain a sense of community, meet neighbors, and find workout buddies – all while their kids are mingling within eyesight. This is a FREE way to enjoy the beautiful South Florida outdoors, get active, spend time together as a family, and show the kids that fitness and healthy choices are important at all ages.

comments.comment: Wonderful idea! I see BP 4 Life as a great way to build community and promote a healthy lifestyle. Count my family in! Thanks for the great proposal!
Great idea!!  This would be so valuable for the community, and enhance a space that is already a treasured part of the neighborhood.
What a wonderful idea to enrich a community by increasing the health of all of its residents and the utilization of the existing outdoor areas.

BP 4 LIFE makes so much sense.  I've seen and used these installations in the Grove and in Alice Wainright Park; they're great.  There is no doubt in my mind that BP 4 LIFE enhance the overall quality of life in our precious village by using fitness to foster community and community to promote fitness.  Thanks for proposing this fantastic idea.

properties.description: To create a neighborhood gathering place in a public park or setting in Brickell or Bayside where free dance lessons are available to the community such as Salsa, Ballroom, Swing, Tango and much more! Every day of the week is a new dance lesson!

properties.description: 'Youth Square' is a project for communities in urban areas with little or no access to public facilities for sports and recreation, that combines health, wellness and quality of life for diverse social and educational activities. Activities that, in addition to democratizing access to sport and leisure, encourage digital inclusion and cultural and scientific production, thus becoming a large area of ​​community life. properties.details: A few fun bits of information that explain distance traveled, direction headed and trail-heads nearby would likely be welcome by all.

Paths would be clearly labeled as beginner, intermediate or expert and planned in a manner to minimize self-inflicted accidents.
properties.title: The Rhythm Section
properties.details: Diversity comes in many forms.  On bicycles, riders have many options, like:  style of riding, type of bike, courses to maneuver, routes to take, directions to proceed and even tricks to accomplish.  So, it's only fitting that at some points along the M-PATH, different riders can be exposed to rhythm sections that are designed for a particular and clearly labeled style of riding, so that users can be surprised, engaged and challenged.

properties.submitter_name: Homestead Housing Authority-Oscar Hentschel, Execuitve Director
properties.description: The Homestead Housing Authority would like to convert an open space at the Redland Center into a 10 station vita course with sidewalks, a covered playground, and a picnic area with trees. The Vita Course will use the latest exercise methodologies to provide a tailored workout for teens and adults of all fitness levels. The course will include instructional signage for ab crunch/leg-lifts; cardio stepping; pull-up/dip; chest and back press; stretch; assisted row/push-up; squat press; tai chi wheels and plyometrics. The playground will include a play system for ages 5-12 that is designed to provide whole body strength and an aerobic workout. Benches will be installed around the course. A separate picnic area will include tables and grills.
properties.title: The Redland Center Vita Course Park, Playground and Picnic Area
properties.details: The Redland Center Vita Park would provide a safe, interactive area that would promote physical fitness training. The park would serve all ages and both individuals and families. The Vita Course will allow the public to engage in outdoor physical activity in a family friendly environment. The Redland  Center Vita Course Park will serve hundreds of low to moderate income families living in and around the Redland Center located in Leisure City an unincorporated area in Miami-Dade County.

properties.description: The Homestead Airforce Reserve Park is a large swath of land that struggles to be something more for the community.  Such a large area and not much to do.  It's vastness is ideal for the fastest growing sport in the nation: Discgolf.  I've already discussed this through email with the Miami Dade Department of Parks and Open Spaces and they have responded positively but cannot provide funds for the project.  I've also acquired quotes for all the supplies needed.  For about $6000.00, and the help of volunteers (which I already have through the large community of enthusiasts), we can quickly install an 18 "hole" course that can last for decades , such as the courses found at the Indian Hammocks Park in Kendall.  Thank you for the consideration
properties.title: The Homestead Discgolf Project
properties.details: Discgolf is a large sport throughout the country.  It is the largest growing sport in the nation.  This is not only an added community benefit but also one that can attract tourists that are here for other reasons such as a race events, sport fishing or any of the other countless reasons people visit South Florida.  It would be one of the lowest cost pastimes available to everyone, making the visit a more satisfying venture.  It can lead also lure competive events and interest for even more tourism.  This offers a great opportunity for local folks to get out of their homes and into some fresh air and take pride in the community.  Small chidren and seniors can all share in this sport.  Men and women from all walks of life enjoy Discgolf.

I live between Orlando & Tampa in Polk County where disc golf is outlawed along with dancing (if you do both, that's almost a life sentence).  If this course gets built and there's a tournament, I'll make my first ever trip to Miami just to play it.

Disc golf is an excellent use for this space. It is inexpensive to build and maintain a course (sounds like most of the funding / work will come without a burden to the taxpayers). People of all ages and abilities who enjoy the sport will visit from miles around, and the potential economic benefit to the community from visitors is a great return on a very small investment.  Miami has a great opportunity here to help grow a sport that is quite inexpensive to play and enjoyed by people from many backgrounds.

Disc golf has a Low impact on the environment, it's easy for anyone to play. I travel to Miami often for work and tend to play in Ft Lauderdale more due to the lack of courses in the Miami area.

Disc golf is a great activity for all age groups and does not cost a lot of $ to play. Players can get started with just one disc. Most courses are free to play and help engage people in a healthy lifestyle. Disc golf is a very simple life time activity that can be enjoyed through the later part of life. Similar to other sports, the level of intensity is easily determined by the player; players can play at a competitive level or just play at a leisurely pace as they stroll through the park.

Miami definitely needs more Disc Golf courses.  I would travel from Orlando to come and play it.  Florida is way behind in the quantity and quality of Disc Golf courses when compared to the rest of the country, not even considering we are one of the states that allows for play 365 days a year, as our Parks stay open year long.

Disc Golf is an inexpensive activity that is beneficial to all ages of the community. The equipment is affordable and easy to install, and requires very little maintenance.  People travel from out of county and out of state to play new disc golf courses, directly increasing revenues through tourism. An 18-hole disc golf course would be a great addition for Homestead. Thank you, Bryan

properties.description: The M-PATH runs along the south side of the Coconut Grove CrossFit.  The sidewalk bends in a way that creates a prime location for a simple hardscape instalment of a mini-park.  Given the adjacent land use as a gym and setting within the M-PATH trail, it appears to be a perfect setting for a physical-fitness / activity-oriented public intervention.  The CrossFit Gym would likely be willing to provide minor maintenance and upkeep at the location, provide the general public with professional demonstrations and educate the public on the benefits of physical activity.  Furthermore, the CrossFit Gym may benefit from increased exposure while the general public will gain another exciting landmark on the M-PATH.
properties.title: FIT is FUN!  Mini-Park
properties.details: People of all fitness levels could utilize this mini-park both as a resting space along the M-PATH as well as a place for varying their workouts and training intensity.  For example, two cyclists may be at different levels but want to ride and exercise together; this mini-park would simultaneously allow some users to rest and collect themselves in the shade as well as allow other users to increase the intensity of their physical regimen.  Finally, if the proposed Healthy Foods Vendor Hub / Farmers Market were to be developed in the adjacent site, a synergy could form around a healthy / fitness theme, potentially leading to improved public health, increased awareness of healthy lifestyles and expanded support of involved clubs and groups.

comments.comment: Love it

properties.description: My idea is to have a community enjoy and become aware of Disc Golf at the Palmetto Bay Village Center. We want to build a Championship course that will allow the community to enjoy the beautiful landscape and the professional Business Park. The property is used often for events and is perfect to have a Disc Golf Tournament in mid November. We would need to completely install the disc golf course and create new holes in the woods. Once the course is completed, then TEEBOXX and the Miami Disc Golf Club would maintain with help from some volunteers (School kids, Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts the YMCA to name a few). Then this would be a community project that once finished could last over 20 years. We want to build a culture of Disc Golf in Miami and this is our model start.
properties.title: Palmetto Bay Village Center Disc Golf Course
properties.details:
Once there is completion of the disc golf course. The kids, families and seniors can go to the Palmetto Bay Village Center and enjoy playing disc golf together. We can show disc golf to school kids for summer camps, leagues or clinics. Then we have families playing Disc Golf in the PBVC Disc Golf course. This would build a culture to excersice more with your kids while enjoying the outdoors, nature and the sport of Disc Golf in your community. 

Our annual tournaments could become an economic impact to the community businesses. We would have the best local restaurants compete in a Taste of PBVC (with live music, beverages and a great atmosphere for the public).

Disc golf is a great investment in park space. It takes very little money to install a course, and even less to maintain it. Golf courses can utilize marginal park space, as no fancy grass or sidewalks are needed, and holes can easily fit into perimeter spaces. The course can be used year-round, and is a great way for all ages to get outside for a fun activity with minimal equipment costs, making it accessible for all income levels (disc prices start at about $8, and you can play with just one).

properties.description: The goal of this project is to build a fitness zone in Kendall Indian Hammocks Park that is appropriate for individuals with differing physical and developmental abilities. This is an idea that came about with the Community Habilitation Center in mind, a center located adjacent to the park committed to helping individuals with disabilities learn community and work skills. Our hope is that this project will be of great benefit to these individuals, as well as everyone in the local area. This is a project that will promote health and wellness for people of all abilities, with particular emphasis on those who often cannot engage in fitness activities due to their disabilities.
properties.name: Fitness Zone Suitable for Individuals with Disabilities
properties.title: Fitness Zone Suitable for Individuals with Disabilities
properties.details: The main purpose of this project is to promote health and wellness for people of all abilities. We are placing particular emphasis on those who often cannot engage in fitness activities due to their physical and developmental disabilities. This project seeks to enhance that opportunity not only for the individuals who are served by the Community Habilitation Center, but for all those who are challenged with disabilities, as well as those who are not disabled and want to be fit and live healthy lives.

properties.details: This bicycle/pedestrian access point would allow Doral and Fountainbleau area residents to make use of this very family friendly path to exercise and enjoy nature.

properties.title: Complete the baywalk gap at Parcel B.
properties.details: Bike/Walk/Run on our amazing waterfront. It is incredible that such a small gap is hindering completion of the Baywalk.

properties.description: Turn main corridors in Coconut Grove (i.e. Grand Avenue, Main Highway, etc) into walking museums that provide interesting historical facts and snapshots for approx. 20 key points of interest via sidewalk stickers and QR codes. The sidewalk stickers will be placed in significant locations with QR code posters either on lampposts or other public street fixtures. Pedestrians will stand on the sticker and use an app on their phone to scan the QR code. The QR code will then link to a page that tells a piece of local history within MiamiOnFut.com (a simple microsite).  Or the QR code could push content to their phone via SMS. Regardless of the delivery method, Miami on Füt will allow the viewer to connect today with yesterday.
properties.title: Miami on Füt
properties.details: Miami on Füt will provide residents/tourists with the opportunity to learn more about this beautiful city in a fun, bite-sized way as they travel on foot to their desired destination. By creatively integrating the experience into the streetscape and making it easy to engage with the content, people of all ages will benefit from increased awareness of the story of Miami. Through this effort, Miami on Füt will help foster a deeper appreciation for the city we know and love today. As the great granddaughter of one of Miami’s pioneers, E.W.F Stirrup, telling the historical narrative of Miami is very close to my heart.  Should this prove successful, Miami on Füt could travel to other neighborhoods to continue building upon the experience.

They could then visit a website when they get home, or perhaps pick up an informational leaflet at a nearby local business. properties.description: South Miami Park is the largest parcel of parkland in the city of South Miami.  However, it is currently a mostly underutilized and empty space with few trees and almost no amenities.  Additionally, the surrounding  neighborhood has no other public parks within 1 mile.  We believe that this space could be transformed into a significant center for the community.  It could be developed to provide active and passive recreational opportunities to citizens of all ages.   It could also be developed in manner that connects people with nature through the use of native plant communities that promote wildlife.  This is a big idea, but we think it can be implemented in phases.  Funding for a running path and a nature playground would be a great start.

properties.details: The space could include such facilities as playgrounds, tennis courts, better soccer fields, running trails, biking paths. natural areas, and educational facilities for the nearby elementary school.  We would like to start with a nature playground and a new running path.

properties.description:
Wynwood is 2 communities: Arts, and low-income Residential.

Arts is mostly cement. Many yards in Residential are incapable of sustaining either humans or wildlife.

UPG & a corporate partner planted 6 micro-habitats along NW 2nd Ave between 22-29 Streets. UPG & NHSSF planted Eatable & Butterfly landscapes in for low-income homeowners. These help families feed themselves, while wildflowers help wildlife and beautification.

Plantings will mostly be near sidewalks for maximum public benefit. Those in private yards will benefit the public with butterflies and birds.

This Pollination Corridor will create a bridge between the 2 communities. Multigenerational resident groups will work with entrepreneurs and artists.
properties.title: Butterflies for Wynwood!
properties.details:
Access to exercise, healthy food, and UPG’s award-winning Experiential Education are intended to benefit the low-income populations nearby. 

Collaborative partnerships with the Arts & Entrepreneurial sectors are hoped to create new economic opportunities. 

It was difficult to select an idea type because there are so many benefits.

Pine Rockland is an Endangered Habitat, virtually wiped out in Wynwood by a century of human development. Each micro-habitat includes both larval (caterpillar) and nectar (adult) foods for butterflies. They form a butterfly pollination corridor along this active street, their wildflowers complimenting dramatic murals… and these connections help prevent butterfly extinctions caused by fragmented populations.

properties.description: Multiple small business vendors could rent designated spaces to sell their items within this space. The vendor would not have to be onsite at all times in order for their merchandise to be sold.  Items could also be tracked through a bar code system for inventory and security purposes.
properties.title: Multi-Purpose vendor space
properties.details: This space would serve the people in the community by: A) Re-using an existing building that was previously an eyesore and lowered community value B) Providing a reasonable and AFFORDABLE booth rent to small business owners to sell their merchandise.  The monthly rental fees would go toward paying for the operational cost of the building space.

properties.description: Provide an Everglades Kitchen Classroom that will bridge the ecology of the Nature Preserve with the nutrition-focused Organic Garden. Located on FIU’s main campus, this much needed public space would be free, accessible, and open to the community to practice organic gardening and food preparation while learning about South Florida’s natural culinary history. The Nature Preserve is Miami’s urban gateway to the Florida Everglades, containing over 250 plants, many of which are edible and were important to Native Americans. And, with the Organic Garden being a center for agricultural research, it makes sense that these outdoor laboratories have been working closely since 2012. Without designated infrastructure both programs have been limited.
properties.title: Everglades Kitchen Classroom
properties.details: Grow/harvest organic produce and indigenous edible plants; learn the importance of healthy eating and of buying locally grown food; understand Florida Native American cuisine; conduct archaeological “digs” for historic rock formations; and search for endangered species in an endangered pine rockland habitat. Having a kitchen classroom directly adjacent to an organic garden will prove how farm-to-table eating really works. A teaching facility would allow FIU to expand community gardening/natural science programs to Miami-Dade County Schools, local non-profit organizations, and university students. Creating a kitchen classroom nestled between a piece of the Florida Everglades and an organic garden would be unique and absolutely priceless.

comments.comment: love the idea!

Love the idea and believe it's only natural to combine the two programs that work so close to each other anyways. There would need to be a considerable supply of these edible natives planted throughout the preserve so that the classroom can have readily available harvests to work with. I think having the edibles planted throughout the preserve (instead of a single, designated area) would create the unique opportunity for students to experience the gathering practices of the Native Americans; going out into the forest would mimic this.
This seems like a great idea. My only concern is that the shelter is larger than the garden.  Is this drawn to scale ?

properties.description: Transform additional green space within the Innercity or Urban Community of Allapattah into vibrant gardens that can serve to build and connect community;  to build generational bridges between wise seniors and inquisitive, enthusiastic youth, many of whom have never seen a Tomatoe grow; while at the same time influencing healthier eating habits.
properties.title: One Tomatoe, Two Tomatoe
properties.details: Experience the benefits and joy of growing, marketing, and eating fresh vegetables while embracing healthier life styles.

properties.description:
Feeding South Florida’s great idea: To transform a weed-filled lot in the heart of one of Miami’s poorest and underserved neighborhoods into an Urban Community Garden, that will improve the health of the residents, give them a sense of pride and accomplishment, act as a community gathering point, and provide a sustainable source of fresh and nutritious food. 

Imagine an entire community working together to turn that lot into a lush garden, brimming with leafy lettuce and plump red tomatoes, an object of beauty in the midst of an otherwise gray environment. 

The garden will allow residents to create a plan to maintain it, be a co-op market accepting SNAP benefits, and an educational experience for children. The site may change.
properties.title: Transforming a Neighborhood
properties.details: An Urban Community Garden brings neighbors together, building relationships that lead to cooperation and self-government to sustain the project. It provides fresh, nourishing fruits and vegetables for families who live in a community with no super markets, fresh food that leads to better health and less sickness for the residents. It beautifies the community and gives impetus for neighborhood renewal. It provides an opportunity to teach children important lessons about the environment and working together. It creates a sense of deep pride and accomplishment that can change lives. It will act as an example for other neighborhoods to emulate. And, ultimately, it will foster the transformation of entire Miami neighborhoods.

properties.description:
One of our ideas to create positive solutions and provide safe spaces for consensus-based dialogues is to provide fresh, organic food in a communal space. The garden aims to provide a space for the public to invest in a process of community, self-actualization, sustainability, and love for thy neighbor. 

Our organization is completely open and welcomes all visitors and volunteers. At the garden we embrace and incorporate the ideals of permaculture in our projects; closed systems, zero waste, care for the earth, and care for all beings. We have built a compost station, begun nurturing a worm culture station, and begun planting in multiple styles of beds. With the help of the Public Space Challenge we will be able to expand our project.
properties.title: Community Garden | Permaculture Awareness
properties.details:
The garden would be a harmonious place to integrate all cultures in Miami, while having common ground in working with the ground. People could engage with the community through learning about creating sustainable permanent culture.

People can use the functional garden to socialize with neighbors, while having access to the healthy edible choices growing in the garden. The garden serves as a space that cultivates conscious living.

The garden provides knowledge, inspiration and education for all.

R.Y.P.E seeks to bring the community together through empowerment, permaculture, and art. We strive to create a space that nourishes a reverence for life through the arts and direct action.

comments.comment:
USDA grant money is available for organic farmers or transitioning to organic.  Up to $20,000. is available.   for further information - 
http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/detailfull/national/programs/financial/eqip/?&cid=nrcs143_008224

These hard-working and creative people have shown what is possible with sweat equity. UPG has provided them with advice, donated plants and other services (our resources are limited). This project is worthy of greater support.
respect your people everywhere! <3 R.Y.P.E
Great project for our community!
I Love This Garden and the Community that Tends to it!

properties.description: The main thoroughfares in Overtown (north and south along 95) and its major cross streets (NW8th, NW11th, NW14th, NW20th) desperately need better food and grocery options. There are the wholesale fruit markets over on NW 12th Avenue and NW 21st Street but those are not accessible to the public, and the mobile trucks cannot be found dependably. I would like to set up fruit and vegetable vendors just like they have in NYC (Green Carts). Locals would be allowed to operate these carts, getting wholesale fruit prices and passing on the savings while providing much needed produce to the residents of this historic neighborhood. The only options are bodegas with bulletproof windows and doors; we need better choices!
properties.title: HEALTHY EATS IN OVERTOWN!
properties.details: This gives the residents of Overtown a fighting chance to stay healthy, and contribute to the vibrant nature of the city. Historic Overtown has always taken hits, and what they need is a helping hand that brings down the scary numbers when it comes to chronic diseases like diabetes, hypertension and obesity. It starts with the home, and it starts with providing access to healthy fresh fruits and vegetables. We are not talking fancy organic; we are talking about accessible, realistic vegetables, indigenous to the culture and residents, provided fresh daily at wholesale cut-rate, ready to sell and ready to cook that night. We can do better for our city, and it starts with giving a fighting chance to the children and families.

comments.comment: great idea. keep ALL our citizens healthy.

properties.description:
My idea is simple, it is simply to bring fruit trees along the aisles of Kendale Lakes. I have an edible landscaping company and I pride myself in my ability to give a landscape that produces many fruits, vegetables and herbs. This street project will be a beautiful addition to any neighborhood and it will be sure to stimulate community interaction, enabling people to get active, walk around and communicate with one another. 

This project will also be a collaboration between many organizations bringing volunteers together, in an effort to mobilize gardeners young and old in order to have a more significant impact in their surrounding areas and community in the city of Miami.
properties.title: Fruit Tree Lane of Kendale Lakes
properties.details: The Fruit Tree Lane will encourage people to exit their homes and take a stroll, the overall benefit can be quantified in added social cohesion that will occur as a result of the beauty and utility Fruit Tree Lane will provide. The fact of the matter is, if the residents of a community will feel a stronger connection with a beautiful space that they can call their own. This public classroom will provide residents and visitors alike eye candy as well as candy for the body and soul. Nature's candy no doubt has a much more significant impact on the daily life of those who live as healthy as they possibly can, eating fruits and vegetables bringing balance into their diets.

comments.comment: Some may say it will attract rodents, but I've always thought we should have as many fruit trees around, mango, avocado, etc... I would also love to see this happen.
Id love to see this happen!

properties.description:
Tree 0 Thrive's GardenTops initiative is a community focused initiative that is sure to make sustainable practices more accessible to the everyday person, we aim to do this by using unused roof space and transforming them into highly functional works of art that are beneficial for the surrounding communities in which we install them.

Smart Bites aims to be a hub for healthy eating through it's A1 meal concierge service catering to individuals who wish to learn how to grow their own food, reduce their ecological footprint all while instilling pride in the surrounding communities. Rooftop garden are sure to become a staple of the future and sustainability and because of this fact these GardenTops will be highly desirable for communities.
properties.title: GardenTops [rooftop gardens]
properties.details:
Once our first GardenTop is built people will realize how fantastic it is to grow your own food and keep your own garden, repurposing of space which will be so paramount for Miami and it's efforts in the field of sustainability. 

First and foremost this space will be providing much benefit to this local business by providing many fruits, veggies and herbs for the local establishment. Another key use of this facility will be as a learning center that will give step by step instruction on how to work the process from start to finish. How the various pieces of our GardenTop works and how it will be used as a model to bring many more rooftop gardens to the Miami area in an effort to beautify our spaces and improve communities.

properties.description: Keeping culture and our lives fresh, a Farmers Market at the Adrienne Arsht Center will activate its public outdoor space, promoting healthier lifestyles and civic engagement in Miami’s most rapidly changing neighborhood. A series of green markets at the Center will expand its role as a community gathering spot and encourage foot traffic and a sense of belonging in a once-desolate stretch that connects Overtown, Museum Park, Wynwood and downtown Miami.
properties.title: FEED YOUR BODY & SOUL
properties.details: Discover the arts and each other while browsing produce booths, sampling food and interacting with neighbors across several city blocks where a growing number of people and businesses are moving. The Center’s outdoor plazas provide visitors with an art-filled destination for connecting with each other and with local vendors. The plazas’ art installations include undulating benches, fountains, and mosaics, which were created as part of Miami-Dade County’s Art in Public Places program. This urban oasis has underutilized potential as a public spot for mingling – and nurturing our bodies and souls with fresh food and the arts.

properties.description:
Miami Plant is a community urban farm and education center growing food with and for local Miamians and providing learning opportunities for all people.  Miami Plant’s mission would be to grow fresh and local produce, educate, and help the local community members meet their food needs. Our vision is to serve as a replicable model of a community-based urban food system.
This project will be organized by A.L.T. (Active Living Team) Non-profit organization with the support of local artists, architects and community organizers.
properties.title: Miami Plant: Urban Community Garden
properties.details: Miami Plant would provide hands-on training in food production, healthy eating and environmental sustainability.  The community garden not only provides food for the neighborhood, but also serves as an outlet to make physical activity fun and rewarding.  The Farm itself will serve as a demonstration site to individuals, organizations and government agencies in the Miami Dade area. The site and programs will integrate people of all ages, classes and races to create vibrant and safe communities.

properties.description: Art of Cultural  Evolution is developing a public sustainability hub called Colony1 on a vacant lot belonging to Miami-Dade County. We are proposing a public Food Forest to provide much needed shade and park style public space in Wynwood. Forest gardening is a prehistoric method of securing food in tropical areas. The Food Forest will be a model of the potential we have in Miami to grow diverse and tropical fruits in our own backyards.  Colony1 will facilitate education around the Food Forest by providing the public access to resources such as seeds, plant cuttings, planting advice and reminders about the annual Miami-Dade Fruit Tree give away.  reduce agricultural climate impact, improve our local food security and celebrate growing food.
properties.title: Food Forest at Colony1 Wynwood
properties.details: As we drive over I-95 in the Spring, we notice a canopy of mango trees in flower, this is one indicator of the potential we have in Miami. With everyone inspired to plant more edible trees we create not only food, by restoring canopy, improve air quality, make the street more appealing for pedestrians and cyclists. The goal of the Colony1 Food Forest is to design, plant and grow an edible urban forest garden that inspires our community to gather together, grow our own food and rehabilitate our local ecosystem. Join us to improve public health by regenerating our public land into an edible forest ecosystem.

comments.comment: Brilliant exactly what Miami needs!

Colony 1 and their brand-new site should be provided with support.  UPG (a winner of the Public Space Challenge 2013 for Urban Agriculture) will donate fruit trees to so this young resource will get a strong start.
A great idea!  And the folks behind it have what it takes to get it done!
This project has so much potential.  Looking forward it!

One thing Miami desperately needs is promotion of the sustainability movement. It is crucially important to communities like ours where the environment is a pervasive part of our lives. This is a great way to do that!

properties.submitter_name: Stephanie van Vark/Mikhaile Solomon/Kimberly Curry Smith/Ines Hernandez-Siqueira

properties.details: The GOODBREAD ALLEY PROJECT memorializes and remembers a simpler time when great food and entertainment drew people into Overtown from miles around.
